author: By Ben Hubbard
title: In Confronting Saudi Arabia, Biden Tiptoes With a Close Ally
description: The U.S. has accused Saudi Arabia’s crown prince of ordering the killing of the dissident Saudi writer Jamal Khashoggi but is wary of causing a break with an important Arab partner.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Biden and his administration speak less of calculated interests in dealing with the rest of the world and more of letting values like democracy and human rights guide the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Before Breonna Taylor and George Floyd, There Was Ahmaud Arbery
description: A year after his killing in Georgia,  his death has sparked a bipartisan effort to remake the state’s 158-year-old citizen’s arrest law. But a potentially divisive trial awaits.
content: WAYNESBORO, Ga. — Scores of mourners gathered last week at a rural cemetery for a service to mark the first anniversary of the slaying of Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old Black man who was chased by a trio of white men and shot to death on a residential street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Dana Rubinstein
title: Under Siege Over Sex Harassment Claims, Cuomo Offers Apology
description: Governor Cuomo said on Sunday that he may have been “insensitive or too personal, and that some of my comments, given my position, made others feel in ways I never intended.”
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Sunday sought to stem the growing political fallout over fresh allegations of sexual harassment, acknowledging that he may have made inappropriate remarks that could “have been misinterpreted as an unwanted flirtation” to a young female aide during private meetings last spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: On TV, a Rare Realistic Look at Breastfeeding
description: A commercial from the parent products company Frida, to be broadcast during the Golden Globes, is part of a wider effort to show the struggles of the “fourth trimester.”
content: Companies are constantly on my case about breasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: Brazil Is Brilliant at Vaccinations. So What Went Wrong This Time?
description: It’s not hard to work out who to blame for the country’s disastrous vaccine rollout.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — When it comes to Covid-19 vaccination programs, there are some countries that have exceeded expectations and others that have fallen surprisingly short. And then there is Brazil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Coplan Hurowitz and Amanda Benchley
title: Get Your Hands Dirty With a Paper-Pulp Sculpture
description: The artist Wangechi Mutu uses pulped newspaper as a material for her sculptures. You can too.
content: The artist Wangechi Mutu, whose seven-foot-tall bronze sculptures of caryatids were the first pieces of art ever displayed in the niches of the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s facade, works in many media, including drawing, painting and video. To fuel her creative output, she constantly experiments with natural materials, many of which she finds or makes from scratch. One of these is paper pulp, an oatmeal-like mush from which she made five orb-shaped “Earth Androids” for the book “Open Studio, Do-It-Yourself Art Projects by Contemporary Artists,” published last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: The Little Magazine That Incubated Team Biden
description: Democracy, an unassuming policy journal with an office near the White House, is a place where members of the new administration have floated ideas that may now become policy.
content: It has only 500 subscribers. And yet Democracy: A Journal of Ideas, a 15-year-old quarterly run by a three-person staff out of a small office blocks from the White House, may be one of the most influential publications of the post-Trump era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William D. Cohan
title: The Private Equity Party Might Be Ending. It’s About Time.
description: A recent legal decision may force Wall Street to think twice before saddling struggling companies with debts they can’t handle.
content: In the early 1980s, William Simon, a former secretary of the Treasury, and Ray Chambers, a former investment banker in New Jersey, made a fortune buying Gibson Greetings Inc. using very little of their own money and then selling it. Each man reaped a windfall of $70 million from an initial investment of $330,000. Ever since, the alchemy of leveraged buyouts has been dazzling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: An Old Legal Doctrine That Puts War Criminals in the Reach of Justice
description: Universal jurisdiction, the idea that any nation’s courts can try people for atrocities committed anywhere, has gained as a tool of human rights lawyers battling impunity.
content: After a decade of war in Syria, people accused of committing atrocities in the service of President Bashar al-Assad are finally facing prosecution — but in Germany and France, not Syria. Three decades after unspeakable crimes in Liberia that left 250,000 dead, defendants are on trial in Switzerland, Finland and elsewhere — but not Liberia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: As School Closures Near First Anniversary, a Diverse Parent Movement Demands Action
description: Frustrated with remote learning, parents in the Philadelphia area are running for office, suing, relocating and retreating to private school.
content: Aquené Tyler, a mother and hair stylist in North Philadelphia, has been disappointed in her neighborhood’s public schools for many years. There were too few books and computers. Even before the pandemic, some schools were shuttered for asbestos removal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Salvaged From 1941 Shipwreck, Letters Reveal Wartime Love and Sacrifice
description: For over 70 years, the letters lay undisturbed in the wreckage of the S.S. Gairsoppa, sheltered from the ravages of ocean currents by well-positioned mail bags. Now, conservators are piecing together these undelivered messages from the past.
content: “Imagine that I have my lips tight against yours with my arms around you tight … hearts beating as one,” a serviceman stationed in India told his beloved, Iris, in 1941.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Olympians Enter a Risky New Event: Line Jumping
description: Some nations are prioritizing Olympians for vaccinations. Others say athletes will wait their turn. The choices could determine if the Tokyo Games are a sporting spectacle, or a superspreader event.
content: In the ongoing calculus of how to distribute limited supplies of the coronavirus vaccine, the broad global consensus often starts with a few groups: doctors and nurses, the ill and the aging, frontline workers and teachers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Salvador’s Leader, Combative but Popular, May Tighten Grip in Elections
description: Nayib Bukele, who has drawn criticism abroad for his strongman displays, is expected to expand his mandate in legislative elections that could deliver his party a decisive victory.
content: MEXICO CITY — In his first two years in office, El Salvador’s president marched soldiers into the country’s legislature, defied Supreme Court rulings, published photos of barely clothed gang members crammed together on a prison floor and dispatched the military to detain anyone breaking quarantine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Vaccine, Stimulus, Trump: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: The impact of the storm in Texas could lead to more virus cases, experts say.
description: Texas' recent storm eyed as possible superspreader
content: More than a week after a powerful winter storm barreled through Texas, some experts say that the conditions — which forced hundreds of people across the state to huddle together in homes, cars and shelters to seek warmth — could lead to an increase in coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Biden administration officials tried to tamp down expectations for supplies of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine.
description: The committee’s approval echoed the Food and Drug Administration’s decision on Saturday to authorize the vaccine for emergency use.
content: One day after federal regulators authorized Johnson & Johnson’s Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use, senior Biden administration officials warned Sunday that the supply of the new vaccine would be highly uneven for the next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: The City Where Cars Are Not Welcome
description: As automakers promise to get rid of internal combustion engines, Heidelberg is trying to get rid of autos.
content: HEIDELBERG, Germany — Eckart Würzner, a mayor on a mission to make his city emission free, is not terribly impressed by promises from General Motors, Ford and other big automakers to swear off fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Emily Schmall
title: China Appears to Warn India: Push Too Hard and the Lights Could Go Out
description: As border skirmishing increased last year, malware began to flow into the Indian electric grid, a new study shows, and a blackout hit Mumbai. It now looks like a warning.
content: WASHINGTON — Early last summer, Chinese and Indian troops clashed in a surprise border battle in the remote Galwan Valley, bashing each other to death with rocks and clubs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Johnson & Johnson has planned trials of its vaccine that will include infants.
description: The company’s coming trials will also involve pregnant women and people whose immune systems are compromised.
content: Johnson & Johnson plans to test its coronavirus vaccine in infants and even in newborns, as well as in pregnant women and in people who have compromised immune systems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Making Black Lives, Not Just Black Deaths, Matter Onstage
description: The tragedy of racism is only part of the story in two very different plays from London that carry a dimension of meaning not usually seen in this country.
content: As far as theater is concerned, the pandemic has been a paradox, shrinking life down to lockdown bubbles and simultaneously expanding horizons. When you can stream plays from Europe as easily as from Brooklyn, the world seems more interconnected than in the past — tied together by bonds of humanity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Slow to Shield Its Inmates From Virus
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 28, 2021.
content: “They’re like sitting ducks.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Morgan
title: Settle In for a Cuppa
description: Tea might be the perfect drink for the pandemic winter malaise. Here’s how to start your own ritual.
content: The consumption of tea around the world is second only to water, and it seems to have grown during these crisis-ridden times. TeaTime magazine in Birmingham, Ala., had a 30 percent increase in Facebook followers and a 45 percent increase in Instagram followers over the past year, according to Lorna Reeves, the magazine’s editor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Jason Sudeikis wins best comedic actor for ‘Ted Lasso.’
description: The TV categories are something of an afterthought at the Globes, which draws its power from proximity to the Oscars. The foreign press association has tried to rectify the imbalance in recent years by rallying behind shows that have yet to pop. Globe voters, for instance, helped “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” and “Transparent” gain wider attention. (On the other hand, the less said about their early support for “Mozart in the Jungle,” the better.)
content: The TV categories are something of an afterthought at the Globes, which draws its power from proximity to the Oscars. The foreign press association has tried to rectify the imbalance in recent years by rallying behind shows that have yet to pop. Globe voters, for instance, helped “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” and “Transparent” gain wider attention. (On the other hand, the less said about their early support for “Mozart in the Jungle,” the better.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: A Snag in the Fight for $15
description: Democrats may lose their fight to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour as part of their sweeping stimulus package.
content: Welcome to the end of February. Here’s your quick run-down of the business and tech news to know for the week ahead, and stay warm. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong Charges 47 Democracy Supporters With Violating Security Law
description: Before Sunday, only a handful of people had been formally charged with breaking the law that China imposed last year, which carries a potential sentence of life in prison.
content: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong authorities charged dozens of pro-democracy figures on Sunday with violating the Chinese territory’s harsh new national security law, the latest blow to the dwindling hopes for democracy in the former British colony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough and Christoper Capozziello
title: In Quest for Herd Immunity, Giant Vaccination Sites Proliferate
description: A day at one mass site in Connecticut shows both the promise and the shortcomings of the approach, which is at the center of President Biden’s plan to bring the pandemic to an end.
content: EAST HARTFORD, Conn. — With the nation’s coronavirus vaccine supply expected to swell over the next few months, states and cities are rushing to open mass vaccination sites capable of injecting thousands of shots a day into the arms of Americans, an approach the Biden administration has seized on as crucial for reaching herd immunity in a nation of 330 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Desperate E.U. nations are hunting for coronavirus vaccines — sometimes on a murky open market.
description: In vaccine-hungry, cash-rich Europe, the hunt for more doses has nations trading with one another, weighing purchases from Russia and China, and fielding offers from middlemen ranging from real to outright frauds.
content: In vaccine-hungry, cash-rich Europe, the hunt for more doses has nations trading with one another, weighing purchases from Russia and China, and fielding offers from middlemen ranging from real to outright frauds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott and Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump Wins CPAC Straw Poll, but Only 68 Percent Want Him to Run Again
description: The Conservative Political Action Conference, made up largely of far-right Trump supporters, held two 2024 presidential straw polls. Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida won one that did not include Mr. Trump.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — Nearly four months after he lost the 2020 election, Donald J. Trump was able to celebrate being a winner again on Sunday, after he captured the 2024 presidential straw poll of the Conservative Political Action Conference, while Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida finished first in a second 2024 straw poll covering a field of potential candidates that did not include Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Pogash
title: He Won a Varsity Letter at 16. He Finally Got It When He Was 79.
description: Tom Ammiano, a well-known gay leader in San Francisco, believed his effeminate mannerisms led his New Jersey high school to deny him his letter.
content: He was a skinny high school student who had asthma, a high-pitched voice and effeminate mannerisms. He kept his distance from football players, who he said bullied him, but when his Catholic school in New Jersey formed a track team, Tom Ammiano decided to join.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: ‘And You?’
description: Michael Lieberman makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — In 1964, I was but a wee crossword columnist, but I have a vague memory of my parents taking me to a huge park where there were no swings or slides and I wasn’t allowed to get out of my stroller. The adults were oohing and aahing over things that didn’t seem half as impressive to me as a good sandbox, and what I remember most is that the sweater my parents had dressed me in that day was extremely itchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Spike Lee’s Children Are This Year’s Golden Globe Ambassadors
description: Jackson Lewis Lee and Satchel Lee are the first Black siblings selected to represent “Hollywood’s next generation.”
content: Satchel and Jackson Lewis Lee are headed to Hollywood, but not for long, they say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Derek Khan, Onetime Stylist for Hip-Hop Stars, Dies at 63
description: He was an architect of the over-the-top look known as “ghetto fabulous.” Later, unable to support his own lavish lifestyle, he fell from grace.
content: Derek Khan, a celebrated fashion stylist to hip-hop and R&B stars like Salt-N-Pepa, Pink and Lauryn Hill who later fell far from those glittering heights, died on Feb. 15 at a hospital in Dubai. He was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and David E. Sanger
title: Iran Rejects Nuclear Deal Talks With U.S. Proposed by Europe
description: The rejection came days after President Biden ordered retaliatory strikes against Iranian-backed militias in eastern Syria.
content: Iran on Sunday rejected an offer to negotiate directly with the United States in an informal meeting proposed by Europeans to revive the nuclear deal that President Donald J. Trump exited nearly three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons
title: Here is how Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine differs from Pfizer’s and Moderna’s.
description: A third effective weapon was added to America’s arsenal against the coronavirus on Saturday when the Food and Drug Administration granted emergency use authorization for a vaccine developed by Johnson & Johnson.
content: A third effective weapon was added to America’s arsenal against the coronavirus on Saturday when the Food and Drug Administration granted emergency use authorization for a vaccine developed by Johnson & Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: Kafka Meets Twitch in ‘Letter to My Father’
description: Audience members can shift from camera to camera in this streaming solo show, like security guards keeping watch.
content: Theater instructions used to be simple: Turn off your cellphone and unwrap your candy before the show starts. Now the M-34 company, based in Brooklyn, is recommending that audience members watch a YouTube tutorial before tuning in to its production of Franz Kafka’s “Letter to My Father.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Checked the Counter and the Floor, but I Couldn’t Find It Anywhere’
description: Cutting corners while making lattes, an unusual offer and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Emmanuel Acho to Host ‘The Bachelor’ Television Special
description: Mr. Acho, author of “Uncomfortable Conversations With a Black Man,” will host “After the Final Rose” after the show’s longtime host went on hiatus over comments dismissive of racism.
content: Emmanuel Acho, an author and former National Football League player, will host a post-finale special of “The Bachelor” after the show’s longtime host, Chris Harrison, said he was “stepping aside” after he made comments that were dismissive of racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Dr. Fauci Hosts ‘So You Think You Can Get the Vaccine’
description: The satirical game show on “Saturday Night Live” also lampooned Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York and Gov. Gavin Newsom of California.
content: How do you get a week’s worth of political scandals and pandemic news into a single comedy sketch? And how do you find out if you qualify for a Covid vaccine and, if so, where to get one? “Saturday Night Live” attempted to answer some if not all of these questions with an opening segment about a fictional game show called “So You Think You Can Get the Vaccine,” hosted by Dr. Anthony S. Fauci.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and The New York Times
title: Military Crackdown in Myanmar Escalates With Killing of Protesters
description: At least 18 people were killed during protests, according to the United Nations, with security forces opening fire on crowds.
content: Military forces in Myanmar opened fire on crowds of peaceful demonstrators in several cities on Sunday, killing at least 18 people, the United Nations said, in a violent escalation of the junta’s efforts to suppress weeks of mass protests against its month-old coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Think You Can’t Dance?
description: Online tutorials for TikTok and music-video routines can help prove you wrong. The “WAP” dance is within your reach.
content: In the early days of the pandemic, a strutting, hip-shaking dance trend took over social media: the J. Lo TikTok Challenge, a roughly 30-second piece of choreography from Jennifer Lopez’s Super Bowl halftime performance last year. It was hard to watch the routine and not want to learn it; in video after video, the energy was contagious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik and Joe Coscarelli
title: Lawyer Seeks Criminal Investigation of T.I. and Tiny on Behalf of Multiple Women
description: The Atlanta superstar rapper and his wife have denied allegations that they drugged and sexually assaulted women, and their lawyer called it a “shakedown.”
content: Weeks after accusations of sexual abuse and assault against the rapper T.I. and his wife, Tameka Harris, started circulating on social media, a lawyer has approached law enforcement authorities in two states seeking criminal inquiries, on behalf of 11 people who said they were victimized by the couple or members of their entourage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Sigrid Johnson Was Black. A DNA Test Said She Wasn’t’
description: The surge in popularity of services like 23andMe and Ancestry means that more and more people are unearthing surprises in their ancestry.
content: It all started when Sigrid E. Johnson was 62. She got a call from an old friend, asking her to participate in a study about DNA ancestry tests and ethnic identity. She agreed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: The Ugly Divorce Between Britain and Brussels Is Just Getting Started
description: As trade disputes pile up, the blame game evident in the early months of the split suits domestic political needs on both sides.
content: LONDON — Few people on either side of the English Channel believed that Britain’s exit from the European Union would go off without a hitch. So when horror stories surfaced about rotting shellfish, empty delivery trucks and eye-popping customs fees, many reacted less with shock than grim resignation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: 3 Injured in Manhole Fire and Explosion in Manhattan
description: The explosion damaged cars and storefronts and caused power failures on Manhattan’s East Side, the authorities said.
content: A manhole fire and explosion in Manhattan early on Sunday morning damaged cars and storefronts, caused power failures and injured at least three people, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Republican Hit List at CPAC Is a Warning Shot to His Party
description: In his first public appearance since leaving office, Donald Trump went through, by name, every Republican who supported his second impeachment and called for them to be ousted.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — After days of insisting they could paper over their intraparty divisions, Republican lawmakers were met with a grim reminder of the challenge ahead on Sunday when former President Donald J. Trump stood before a conservative conference and ominously listed the names of Republicans he is targeting for defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Cook With Cabbage and Sing a Sea Shanty
description: This week, get a tarot reading, unwind with a yoga class or learn about pendulums.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 01, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Supreme Court Test for What’s Left of the Voting Rights Act
description: While state legislatures consider new voting restrictions to address claims of election fraud, the justices will hear arguments on what kind of legal scrutiny such laws should face.
content: WASHINGTON — As Republican state lawmakers around the nation are working furiously to enact laws making it harder to vote, the Supreme Court on Tuesday will hear its most important election case in almost a decade, one that will determine what sort of judicial scrutiny those restrictions will face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Three Wichita Officers Injured by ‘Modified’ Shotgun, Police Say
description: The officers were checking on a vacant home when they were injured by a shotgun that discharged as they entered, the police said.
content: Three Wichita, Kan., police officers who had been dispatched to check on a vacant house were injured on Saturday when a “modified, loaded shotgun” discharged as they entered, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 28, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Feb. 28, 2021.
content: An article last Sunday about lab-made foods misidentified the company that makes sake without rice. It is Endless West, not Perfect Day. It also misidentified the ingredient used to make ice cream. It is microflora, not yeast. And it misstated a role that a company, Geltor, has in the making of face cream with fermented spider silk proteins. Geltor produces the proteins; it does not make the cream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: A Day Before He Speaks, Conservative Gathering Is Mostly About Trump
description: At CPAC on Saturday, the focus was on praise for Mr. Trump in advance of his speech there on Sunday.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — A pair of influential House Republicans used a conservative political gathering on Saturday to lavish praise on former President Donald J. Trump and, in ways subtle and direct, marginalize their G.O.P. colleagues who have distanced themselves from Mr. Trump in the aftermath of the Capitol riot last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: After harsh criticism, Israel says it will vaccinate Palestinians who hold work permits.
description: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government approved a measure on Sunday to vaccinate tens of thousands of Palestinian laborers, after facing fierce criticism over the small number of inoculations it had provided to Palestinians living under its military occupation.
content: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government approved a measure on Sunday to vaccinate tens of thousands of Palestinian laborers, after facing fierce criticism over the small number of inoculations it had provided to Palestinians living under its military occupation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Look to spring, and treat yourself to a pasta with fresh herbs, lemon and peas.
content: Good morning. The Golden Globes will be awarded this evening in a ceremony that will not resemble earlier, boozier incarnations of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association’s annual recognition of the shows and films its members were lobbied to herald. Amy Poehler will anchor the broadcast from the Beverly Hilton in Los Angeles, with Tina Fey joining her from the Rainbow Room in New York. The nominees will join via screens in their homes. (Stars, they’re just like us.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: At least 18 protesters killed in Myanmar.
content: The security forces in Myanmar opened fire on demonstrators in several cities on Sunday, killing at least 18 people. It was the largest single-day toll since the protests began after the Feb. 1 coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: The Leon Rose Approach: Way Too Quiet, But Effective for Knicks (So Far)
description: As the team president for the past year, Rose has let the Knicks’ on-court flickers of progress do most of his talking.
content: The Knicks had just sullied their better than expected start with a loss at home to the Miami Heat, but the more pressing topic on Feb. 7 was a looming trade. A deal with the Detroit Pistons was about to position the Knicks’ Tom Thibodeau to coach Derrick Rose for the third time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Seniors Seeking Vaccines Have a Problem: They Can’t Use the Internet
description: Older adults living alone often lack access or an understanding of technology, and many are unsure how to sign up for an appointment.
content: Annette Carlin feels trapped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Two Sluggers Aren’t Quite Done, but the End Is Near
description: Albert Pujols and Miguel Cabrera, two of the greatest hitters in baseball history, will be back for 2021. Whenever they retire, they will leave an enormous void.
content: Two old baseball gods, long since surpassed by a younger generation of stars, are both aware that their days on the field are numbered. But Albert Pujols and Miguel Cabrera aren’t ready to leave just yet, no matter what you’ve heard. They have unfinished business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Era of Vaccine Diplomacy Is Here
description: The coronavirus threat is global. So is the remedy.
content: It is only natural that the American government and the American people have focused on getting coronavirus vaccines to as many of its people as possible, with the most vulnerable first in line. But as the pace of domestic vaccination accelerates, two facts are worth bearing in mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: How the Pandemic Stalled Peak TV
description: Where’s “Succession”? “Atlanta”? After the number of scripted shows fell for the first time in a decade, Hollywood hopes to satisfy a restless audience with less costly fare.
content: What would we be watching in an alternate, pandemic-free universe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Hamadey
title: How to Write a Gratitude Letter
description: Concerned about a friend or a loved one who may be feeling the winter doldrums? Try writing them a gratitude letter.
content: If you are looking to make someone — even yourself — feel better during what has been a hard winter of the pandemic, consider writing a gratitude letter. You can think of it as a slightly longer and more meaningful thank you note, but instead of offering thanks for a physical gift, you are offering thanks for something that was done or said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Yankees Feel Butterflies Before Playing in Front of a Crowd
description: Spring training started with a loss to Toronto, but Yankees players were just happy to have fans back. “It felt a lot more normal.”
content: TAMPA, Fla. — The gates at Steinbrenner Field opened at 11 a.m. Sunday, two hours before the Yankees hosted the Toronto Blue Jays for their first spring training game of 2021. Among the first fans to enter: Robert and Jean Koontz, who have been making this yearly trip from their home in North Carolina for two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Plastic Surgeon Attends Video Traffic Court From Operating Room
description: California’s Medical Board started an investigation after Dr. Scott Green reported for the hearing on Zoom while in scrubs and with a patient on the operating table.
content: The Medical Board of California said it was investigating a plastic surgeon who attended a video traffic court hearing from an operating room while dressed in scrubs and with a patient on the surgical table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: African-American Sacrifice in the Killing Fields of France
description: They fought and died as heroes for their country in World War I, only for segregation to persist.
content: SÉCHAULT, France — The modest granite monument at the entrance to Séchault, a village in eastern France, commemorates the sacrifice of the United States 369th Infantry Regiment, African-Americans who came from Harlem to fight in the last months of World War I. A single word in brackets, “Colored,” alludes to the official name of the New York National Guard unit from which the soldiers were drawn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: At CPAC, a Golden Image, a Magic Wand and Reverence for Trump
description: The faithful who flocked to the annual conference of conservatives made it clear that their allegiance was to the former president far more than to the Republican Party.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — Tommy Zegan was appalled by the few sculptures of Donald J. Trump in existence — the life-size nude statue that popped up in major cities in America, the golden toilet in London. So in 2018, he got to work.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Honoring Tiger Woods, in Red and Black
description: Woods’s signature final-round outfit was seemingly everywhere in the golf world on Sunday.
